conclusion: Use the ideal gas law PV = nRT to find the temperature of the gas in state B.
Explanation of variables in the ideal gas law: P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles, R is ideal gas constant, T is temperature.
Given temperature at state C is 300 K and need to find temperature at state B.
At state C: P_C = 1 x 10^5 Pa and V_C = 2 x 10^-3 m^3.
At state B: P_B = 2 x 10^5 Pa and V_B = 5 x 10^-3 m^3.
Since n and R are constant, use relation P_C V_C / T_C = P_B V_B / T_B.
Substitute known values into the relation: (1 x 10^5) x (2 x 10^-3) / 300 = (2 x 10^5) x (5 x 10^-3) / T_B.
Determine the temperature of the gas in state B is 150000 K.
